fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is the forest of my notes on Mathematics. It's an attempt to describe the "mental landscape" of Mathematics, at least how I view it (based on how I learned it).

fr:title.text: Naive handling of material followed by rigorous presentation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Naive handling of material followed by rigorous presentation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is a "naive" introduction to some of the material: in Elementary linear algebra, for example, we just assume the real numbers exist and familiarity with calculating with them (at least to the level expected of a calculus student). But it isn't until Classical Analysis where constructing real numbers is really examined.

Arguably this "circular" treatment of material is a pedagogical virtue when actually "executed" in practice: the student will study Elementary linear algebra one quarter, then intermediate linear algebra the next quarter, then Classical Analysis the following quarter. This spaces out the material and the review, which strengthens mental connections.

For better or worse, this forest of notes lacks that quality. After all, you can sit down and just "cram" the notes, possibly over the course of several days. So for you, the reader, you will not have the advantage of spaced learning.
Also I am being a bit sparse when giving proofs in the earlier parts of the forest. So Elementary linear algebra lacks proofs for every theorem, but they could be supplied if desired.

The choice to order material partially reflects how I learned it (Elementary linear algebra, followed by intermediate linear algebra, then Classical Analysis, and so on) and partially how I mentally think of the material: linear algebra is the "central" subject in Mathematics, and everything "branches off" from it.
This means we successively review linear algebra in greater generality.

Moreover, I have decided to "cluster" trees into "subforests" reflecting the course materials. This means each "identifier" for a tree is prefixed by some "slug" for the "subforest". Sometimes (like with field or sl) a mathematical object or gadget is used as the slug. Othertimes (like with ela or ca) the course name is used.
This roughly corresponds to my "mental model" of Mathematics as I have learned it. For more rambling about this, see the Preface.
